articles.title: Volcanic Threat Escalates: Scientists Warn of Increased Danger
articles.summary: There is a link between global warming and increased volcanic activity, according to a new study. Volcanic eruptions can contribute to long-term global warming due to the accumulation of greenhouse gases. The Pacific Ring of Fire is witnessing increased activity at volcanoes in Japan, Indonesia, the Philippines, and the western coasts of North and South America. Iceland is showing signs of renewed activity.

articles.author: EDITH MUTETHYA

Global share of people over 65 years old will rise from 10 percent in 2024 to 16 percent by 2050. articles.summary: On July 22, Earth will spin about 1.38 milliseconds faster than its typical 86,400 seconds in a day. On July 5, 2024, the fastest day since the introduction of the atomic clock occurred when the day was truncated by 1.66 milliseconds. The northern hemisphere is tilted toward the sun, which minimizes the difference in temperature between the equator and Earth's poles.

articles.summary: As California's Central Valley continues to heat up, agriculture workers face long working hours, hotter conditions, and increased risk of poor health. articles.title: Earth's fastest rotations — and shortest days — are predicted for this summer. Here's what to know.

In the past 130 years, the variation in length of the day has ranged by a couple of milliseconds. Wind speed and the Earth's rotation influence the changes in the length and speed of day.

Switzerland comes closest with climate change being named as a severe issue by the fifth-highest number of respondents, followed by China in rank 6. Despite ranking only seventh in Italy, climate change was recognized as a big problem there by more people. Italy's percentage was the highest in the survey, while China's and Japan's were the lowest.

articles.title: Global warming seen in Eastern Shore forests
articles.summary: Temperatures in Maryland have risen 2.5 degrees Fahrenheit since the 20th century. The state is experiencing increasing precipitation, a higher probability of summer droughts, more extreme weather events and flooding accompanied with rising sea levels. Communities on the Eastern Shore and Baltimore's city neighborhoods are at particular risk.

articles.title: Increase in outdoor fires due to hot weather, says fire service
articles.author: Zhara Simpson
articles.summary: Devon and Somerset Fire and Rescue service has seen an increase in outdoor fires this year in comparison with previous years. articles.title: Sparking new ideas on how wildfire influences climate
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: Wildfires have spread across the planet for millennia. They are increasing as the climate warms and forests are decimated by climate change. It's a problem for the future of the planet. It will be worse in the future if the climate continues to warm.

articles.title: Moscow sizzles in record-breaking heatwave
articles.author: AFP
articles.summary: Moscow swelters in a heatwave with temperatures topping 35 degrees Celsius (95 degrees Fahrenheit) on Friday. articles.summary: June 2025 was the world's third-warmest June on record, according to the EU-funded Copernicus Climate Change Service. Western Europe experienced its warmest June ever, with temperatures averaging 20.49 degrees. An 'exceptional' marine heatwave developed in the western Mediterranean, where daily SSTs peaked at 27 degrees.

articles.title: Cold front hits Western Cape again
articles.author: Lulama Klassen
articles.summary: The Western Cape is bracing for another brutal cold front this Friday. The provincial Disaster Management Centre has issued urgent warnings. A Yellow level 2 alert for damaging waves is in effect from Hondeklip Bay to Plettenberg Bay until Saturday.

articles.title: Auckland steam ferry needs $5m to get afloat

The number of Kiwis who left for Australia last year was the highest in more than a decade, according to Stats NZ's statistics. It comes after Stats NZ said the number of New Zealanders leaving for Australia was highest in a decade.

articles.title: Gripes and gaggles: Wrights Lake residents battle growing goose population
articles.author: Chris Woodard
articles.summary: There is a surge in Canada geese at Wrights Lake. Cabin owners are concerned the geese could damage the ecosystem surrounding the lake. There may be as many as 70 geese around the lake at any given time. The problem has escalated over the past five years.

articles.title: Earth's Speeding Up: A July-August Spin Surge
articles.summary: Earth's rotation has been accelerating. July and August of 2025 could bring the shortest days in recent memory. The Earth's rotation isn't constant and it fluctuates due to a complex interplay of factors. The current acceleration is prompting discussion among geophysicists and timekeepers worldwide.

articles.title: Federal agency cuts contributed to tragedy
articles.summary: Donald Trump's administration's cuts to NOAA and NWS contributed to the loss of life in Texas. It is short-sighted and dangerous to continue to deny climate change. Cyndi Kehoe expects more violent and disastrous storms with heartbreaking results if the funds for these critical agencies are not restored.

articles.title: Hot weather in England to kill 50 times more people by 2070
articles.author: Alexander Butler
articles.summary: A study warns that heat-related deaths in England and Wales could increase 50-fold by the 2070s, potentially reaching over 34,000 under a 4.3C warming prediction. The 2022 summer saw temperatures exceeding 40C and nearly 3,000 heat- related deaths.

articles.title: Soaring temperatures drive surge in global milk prices
articles.author: Alimat Aliyeva
articles.summary: Climate change is undermining the foundations of dairy farming. Extreme heat can reduce milk production by up to 10%. It can take more than 10 days for milk production to return to normal after a hot spell. Global milk production could decrease by 4% by mid-century if no action is taken.

articles.title: Only 17% of American adults believe climate change will impact where they live: Gallup poll
articles.author: Thomas Stevenson
articles.summary: Gallup poll shows that Americans are not that concerned about climate change. Only 17 percent of adults think it will impact where they live, compared to 6 percent of Republicans, 16 percent of Independents and 27 percent of Democrats. In 2020, 46 percent of Americans are "greatly worried" about it, but in 2025, it will drop to 40 percent.

articles.title: Chantal flooding shows NC still has much to learn from Helene tragedy
articles.author: The Herald-Sun
articles.summary: There was severe flooding in central North Carolina due to climate change and a lack of flooding mitigation, says an opinion piece by John Sutter. Sutter says the flooding was caused by climate change, not by lack of mitigation measures.

articles.title: Is There Still Time to Be Hopeful About the Climate?
articles.author: Daniel A. Gross
articles.summary: A clock in New York's Union Square has been counting down to zero for the past five years. It represents humanity's shrinking opportunity to limit global warming to a long-term average of 1.5 degrees Celsius (2.7 degrees Fahrenheit). Earth is already hot enough that climate disasters are spreading and intensifying.

articles.title: Oxfordshire A-road closed off after fire breaks out
articles.author: Matt Simpson
articles.summary: The A417 is closed between Blewbury and Goring due to a wildfire. Oxfordshire Fire and Rescue Service was called to the field fire shortly after 1.30pm. A heatwave bringing high temperatures over most of the UK from Friday has increased the risk of fires starting.

articles.title: Letter: Do we even care about climate change?
articles.author: JOSEPH BRUSBERG

articles.title: Arizona's Skies Diminished My Passion for Flying
articles.summary: Arizona's distinctive weather patterns, particularly its powerful thermals, present a stark contrast to the conditions commonly found in other regions. Over the last decade, a noticeable decline in visibility has considerably impacted the flying experience for many pilots. The issue centers around increasing air pollution, dust storms, and the growing impact of wildfire smoke.

articles.title: FAO and St Lucia's agriculture ministry launch the islands biggest fisheries project

It aims to modernize Saint Lucia's fisheries sector by improving safety standards, increasing yields, and fostering a circular economy that minimizes waste and promotes sustainable resource use. Over a span of five years, it will impact 75,000 people, including 13,000 directly involved and 62,000 indirectly.

articles.title: Penguin chicks cool off during heatwave with dip in zoo's pool
articles.author: Ellie Crabbe

articles.title: Hardening history for future storms: How much to raise

The process of gutting the house to raise it is extensive.

articles.title: Global warming may create a "permanent El Nino", changing the world's weather patterns
articles.author: Ben Aris in Berlin

It follows a couple of scientists to the Antarctic, oceanographer Dr Natalie Robinson and microbiology PhD candidate Jacqui Stewart.

articles.title: 'Militant' geese take over Franklin in viral TikTok marching clip

articles.title: Climate change poses mounting threat to India's data centres, warns global report

articles.title: Curtailing trade hurts poor nations looking to adapt to climate change

The world's poor nations tend to be located in the hotter parts of the planet and are disproportionately agrarian. New research shows that climate change will reduce agricultural productivity most severely in hot regions. However, high temperatures harm agricultural productivity, but have a smaller impact on manufacturing and services than in agriculture.

articles.title: Australia's climate visa: A model for sinking islands?
articles.author: Deutsche Welle
articles.summary: Tuvalu is extremely vulnerable to climate change and rising seas. Australia signed the Falepili Union Treaty in November 2023. From 2025, a "special mobility pathway" has opened up that allows up to 280 Tuvaluans to live, work or study in Australia each year. People who win the ballot can move freely without being locked into a job or course.

articles.title: Amber heat health alert issued across southern UK amid risk of increased deaths

articles.title: Earth's rotation speeding up, leading to slightly shorter days: Report

articles.title: Duration of heat waves is accelerating faster than climate change, study shows
articles.author: Clara Harter

Longer heat waves will dry out vegetation and increase the danger of wildfires in Southern California. articles.title: Letter to Editor: Kashmir's Lakes Are Dying and We're Still Debating

articles.title: ‘It can't withstand the heat': fears ‘stable' Patagonia glacier in irreversible decline

articles.title: Heat deaths in England could rise 50-fold in next half century, study warns
articles.author: Michael Peel
articles.summary: Heat-related deaths in England and Wales would rise 50-fold over the next half-century if climate change is severe and adaptations are minimal, according to the study published in the journal PLoS on Thursday. Under the most optimistic scenario, deaths would climb six-fold.

articles.title: Climate Shifts Extending Sydney's Bull Shark Season
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Migratory bull sharks are staying 15 days longer off Sydney's coast during the summer than they did 15 years ago. This is due to rising water temperatures. JCU Postdoctoral Research Fellow Dr Nicolas Lubitz said continued climate change could transform seasonal shark patterns, potentially leading to a year-round bull shark presence in southern New South Wales in the future.

articles.title: COP30: Call to action against climate disinformation
articles.author: APA
articles.summary: The Global Initiative for Climate Change Information Integrity launched a public call on Thursday to identify and elevate concrete efforts to counter climate disinformation ahead of COP30 in Belém, Brazil. The initiative brings together the United Nations, UNESCO, the UNFCCC, Brazil, and six other countries (Chile, Denmark, France, Morocco, Sweden, and the United Kingdom) as well as civil society partners. Selected proposals may be featured in the official programme of the COP30, scheduled for November 2025. For the first time, information integrity has been included in the COP agenda.

articles.title: Antarctic summer sea ice at record lows
articles.author: The Hindu
articles.summary: Recent low sea-ice summers present a scientific challenge. The system is changing faster than the scientific community can study it, says Dr. Richard Brignall.      Â   in the article "The Changing Sea-Ice System" by Richard Brinall.

articles.title: NOAA staffing, budget cuts raise concerns over forecasting
articles.author: WSOCTV.com News Staff
articles.summary: There are concerns over the accuracy of hurricane forecasts this year due to staffing and budget cuts at the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. $400 million intended for upgrading and purchasing new hurricane hunting equipment is currently frozen, and the number of researchers qualified to fly on hurricane hunting planes has been reduced by half.

articles.title: What would happen if the Earth continues to spin faster? Stronger hurricanes, disastrous earthquakes and catastrophic flooding, expert says
articles.author: WILIAM HUNTER
articles.summary: On July 22 and August 5, the day will be 1.38 and 1.51 milliseconds shorter than average. This is because the planet's rotation has entered an unexpected period of acceleration. It takes the planet 24 hours, or 86,400 seconds, to complete one full rotation, which is called a solar day. If Earth were spinning 100 miles per hour faster than it does now, the world would be hit by stronger hurricanes, catastrophic flooding and the collapse of satellite networks.

articles.title: Ghana needs up to $16Bn to implement climate change actions amid economic challenges
articles.author: Modern Ghana
articles.summary: Ghana needs between $9.3 billion and $16.6 billion to fully implement its Nationally Determined Contribution (NDCs) to adapt and mitigate the impact of climate change. The NDCs include 47 specific programmes of action, with 34 focused on mitigation and 13 focused on adaptation.

articles.title: Popular tourist destination on the brink of collapse
articles.author: Schannell Kanyora
articles.summary: The Bahamas is a popular tourist destination. The archipelago's low-lying geography, reliance on tourism, and porous limestone geology make it vulnerable to rising sea levels, increased hurricane intensity, and coastal erosion. Last month, ITV News Correspondent Rachel Younger went to the Islands to talk to locals about how climate change is having a direct impact on their lives.

articles.title: OPINION: As long as developers in Florida run the show, rampant growth will continue
articles.author: Bryon White
articles.summary: In the I-4 corridor, there are 8 million people, more than the entire population of Florida in 1975. Florida has reached the point of diminishing returns on sprawl. Every new subdivision, big-box project, and warehouse complex costs more in infrastructure, emergency services, and disaster mitigation than it ever returns in tax revenue. Florida's political system enables developers to buy influence and influence the political system.

articles.title: Oceans on fire: How marine heatwaves are silently destroying life underwater
articles.author: Divya Danu
articles.summary: Marine heatwaves are getting hotter and lasting longer due to climate change. Underwater heat spells are killing corals, seagrass and fish, affecting marine life, ecosystems and the people who depend on the sea. Divya Danu's writing is driven by reason, shaped by curiosity, and balanced with skepticism.

articles.title: Marjorie Taylor Greene pledges probe into geoengineering
